messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 63 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: OSCAR-Net: Object-centric Scene Graph Attention for Image Attribution

Paper Abstract: Abstract Images tell powerful stories but cannot always be trusted. Matching images back to trusted sources (attribution) enables users to make a more informed judgment of the images they encounter online. We propose a robust image hashing algorithm to perform such matching. Our hash is sensitive to manipulation of subtle, salient visual details that can substantially change the story told by an image. Yet the hash is invariant to benign transformations (changes in quality, codecs, sizes, shapes, etc.) experienced by images during online redistribution. Our key contribution is OSCAR-Net111Code, data and model available at https://exnx.github.io/oscar/ (Object-centric Scene Graph Attention for Image Attribution Network); a robust image hashing model inspired by recent successes of Transformers in the visual domain. OSCAR-Net constructs a scene graph representation that attends to fine-grained changes of every object’s visual appearance and their spatial relationships. The network is trained via contrastive learning on a dataset of original and manipulated images yielding a state of the art image hash for content fingerprinting that scales to millions of images.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 63 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 63"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Efficient content based image retrieval using combination of dominant-color shape and texture features and k-means clustering",
        "Specifying object attributes and relations in interactive scene generation",
        "Multi-stakeholder media provenance management to counter synthetic media risks in news publishing",
        "Watermarking scheme for copyright protection of digital images",
        "Transformation-aware embeddings for image provenance",
        "Imagehash",
        "Tamper-proofing video with hierarchical attention autoencoder hashing on blockchain",
        "Hashnet: Deep learning to hash by continuation",
        "A simple framework for contrastive learning of visual representations",
        "Multi-label image recognition with graph convolutional networks",
        "ARCHANGEL: Trusted archives of digital public documents",
        "Social media sites photo metadata test results",
        "A fragile watermarking scheme for image authentication with tamper localization using integer wavelet transform",
        "The deepfake detection challenge (DFDC) dataset",
        "An image is worth 16x16 words: Transformers for image recognition at scale",
        "Security analysis of sha-256 and sisters",
        "Ticks or it didn’t happen",
        "Aligning linguistic words and visual semantic units for image captioning",
        "Dimensionality reduction by learning an invariant mapping",
        "Digital image watermarking in the wavelet transform domain",
        "Mask r-cnn",
        "Deep residual learning for image recognition",
        "The PS-Battles Dataset – an Image Collection for Image Manipulation Detection",
        "Visual pattern recognition by moment invariants",
        "Locality preserving hashing in multi-dimensional spaces",
        "Fast multiresolution image querying",
        "Product quantization for nearest neighbor search",
        "Asymmetric deep supervised hashing",
        "Billion-scale similarity search with gpus",
        "Graph convolutional network for multi-label vhr remote sensing scene recognition",
        "Perceptual video hashing for content identification and authentication",
        "Semi-supervised classification with graph convolutional networks",
        "Perceptual hashing of color images using hypercomplex representations",
        "Deep supervised discrete hashing",
        "Feature learning based deep supervised hashing with pairwise labels",
        "In ictu oculi: Exposing ai created fake videos by detecting eye blinking",
        "Push for quantization: Deep fisher hashing",
        "Scenesketcher: Fine-grained image retrieval with scene sketches",
        "Deep supervised hashing for fast image retrieval",
        "Learning structural similarity of user interface layouts using graph networks",
        "Geometric deep learning on graphs and manifolds using mixture model cnns",
        "Image provenance analysis at scale",
        "Digital-content-based identification: Similarity hashing for content identification in decentralized environments",
        "Content-based watermarking by geometric wrapping and feature- based image segmentation",
        "Content authenticity initiative (CAI): Setting the standard for content attribution",
        "Facenet: A unified embedding for face recognition and clustering",
        "Grad-cam: Visual explanations from deep networks via gradient-based localization",
        "A fast optimization method for general binary code learning",
        "Greedy hash: Towards fast optimization for accurate hash coding in CNN",
        "End-to-end memory networks",
        "Mlesac: A new robust estimator with application to estimating image geometry",
        "Attention is all you need",
        "Graph attention networks",
        "Moviegraphs: Towards understanding human-centric situations from videos",
        "Hashing for similarity search: A survey",
        "Detecting photoshopped faces by scripting photoshop",
        "CNN-generated images are surprisingly easy to spot… for now",
        "Mantra-net: Manipulation tracing network for detection and localization of image forgeries with anomalous features",
        "Central similarity quantization for efficient image and video retrieval",
        "Implementation and benchmarking of perceptual image hash functions",
        "Discovering image manipulation history by pairwise relation and forensics tools",
        "Deep balanced discrete hashing for image retrieval",
        "Deep hashing network for efficient similarity retrieval"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 63 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in OSCAR-Net: Object-centric Scene Graph Attention for Image Attribution, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
